author: mambomonkey8

title: Geta Shoe - Japanese "Wooden Shoe" Mens Size 8

description.text:
The Geta shoe is an example where we can look to the past to see the future. We are no more than five to ten years away from great advances in home 3d printing. The big constraint as I see it, is the ability for end users to design functional items via software. By looking to the past simple designs can be leveraged to take advantage of this emerging technology.

Its very clear that 3d printing at home will transition from a toy making hobby into an important field that will allow people to produce functional and unique items for everyday use. Formlabs is introducing an SLS printer that allows for the printing of heavy duty, high quality, nylon parts at home. For us home designers and enthusiasts, leveraging the past and keeping things simple.

More about the Geta here (including a Geta Calculator)

https://web.archive.org/web/20080115093155/http://www.egeorgeonline.com:80/getapage/

I extended the Sole length 1cm more than anticipated in the calculations below.
I put ridges into the top surface to improve the structure of the sandal, I also added some structure between the "Ha's". I may/may not print this item. For me this was an exercise in building Fusion 360 skills.

A - Sole Length 27
B - Sole Width 12.1
C - Ha Thickness 3.5
D - Front Thong Setback - 4
E - Front Ha Setback - 9.4
F - Rear Ha Set Forward - 3.5
G - Rear Thong Set Forward 7.2
H - Sole Thickness 1.6
J - Ha Height 4.5

title: Audi TT Mk1 roof light holder repair - transparent part

description.text:
The transparent part in the roof light in my Audi TT didn't stay in place. The little "nails" at the tip of the "fingers" were broken, as in the photos.
The part I designed and printed installs over the fingers to replace the nails which bite the spring to stay in place.
You must print two copies, one for each finger. I keep them in place by simple pressure, but they can be glued with cyanocrilate.

La tapa transparente de la luz del techo no se sujetaba en su sitio. Las uñitas al final de los dedos que la tenían que sujetar estaban rotas, ver las fotos.
La pieza que he diseñado se instala sobre los dedos para añadir esa uña que se sujeta en el muelle que hay en el plafón del techo.
Hay que imprimir dos copias iguales, una para cada dedo. En mi caso entran a presión y se sujetan bien, pero también se pueden pegar con cianocrilato.

title: Coin Watch Battery Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a watch battery holder designed for a coin battery. I fabricated it to be used for easy placement on designs at our engineering kids camp this summer. It has holes for wires to be put in both sides. The slot on the bottom piece should line up with the hole on the top piece.

There are 3 .stl files to be downloaded. The first one is both pieces and that would be all you need. The second and third ones are just the top and bottoms to be printed separately. It is tight enough that if you put the battery in and wires in both holes it will stay together effectively. It takes some effort to put it together and take it apart. The best way to get the battery out once the top is off is to push up on it with the wire. We put the positive side up, but it should work fine both ways
It is going to be used with lights and speakers and we are going to have a prefabricated set up to allow the kids to place these electronics directly on their designs.

This is a chainsaw with a working hand cranked chain. It is modeled after a popular brand of chain saws. Most parts require supports. I did all the parts in PLA, but any material you're comfortable with should work. Infill % shouldn't matter for any of the parts. The longest parts are just over 200mm, so they should fit diagonally on most printers. Also, sorry but i still haven't figured out how to orient the stls that get posted here so they are the correct direction for printing so you'll have to rotate most of the parts to print them.

There are 2 versions of the chain, flat and clawed. The flat chain is easier to print and smoother on the skin if you expect it to be attacked with it.

It requires 44 links. The chain is in groups of 6 so print 8 sets of them and you'll have a few extra.

Hardware required (Minimums. All can be a little longer if thats what you have):
Qty 4 - M4 x 12
Qty 6 - M3 x 10
Qty 4 - M3 x 22

author: AdrianMankovecky

description.text:
it is known that tolerances in FDM printing vary between printers a lot.

same happens here:
just after finishing a big print, you have to realize: the flowers don't fit to the stem.
so before you blindly start your 14 hour print, give this little fella a shot:

de-/increase the calibration piece by the same % you did with the flowers, trial-and-error and decrease it a little every time.

for example: i printed my flowers with 50% scale and the stem only with 48% !!!

less plastic wasted!! :-)
I made this samurai logo to put in my room, I share to the samuka fans!

Simple print.

Let it glow, let it glow!

I discovered the best glow in the dark paint whilst working on this project. It's called Aurora and after charging it under a light source it glows incredibly brightly. The down side is that it dries a little grainy but it didn't matter too much in this instance.

The prints were sanded and painted green. I then painted the Aurora into the pattern on the stone surface, wiping away any mistakes or overspill with a tissue (or my finger tips). I sealed it all under a coat of clear varnish.

Despite washing my hands I found my finger tips were still glowing when I went to bed.

The best glow in the dark paint ever.

One of my daughter's favorite games is the Farming Game, a game that teaches you what it is really like to run your own farm. It was created by a farmer from Eastern Washington who developed the idea while driving his tractor.

The pieces for it are all little flat, vinyl cling stickers... that stop sticking after about one or two uses... That just isn't any fun... So, to make things more interesting for my daughter, and to give her a surprise for her birthday, I designed 3D pieces for all the pieces that came with the game.

The Tractor, Harvester, Hay, Grain, and Fruit coins were all my own design, using 123D Design. The cow model came from here: http://us.gallery.xyzprinting.com/us_en/membergallery/model/201507159793842 and was resized for appropriate game board size.

Tractors and Harvesters: These are to represent one tractor or harvester each.

Hay and Grain coins: These are to represent 10 acres of each crop. On the BOTTOM of the coin is "x2" because there are places on the board that will double your harvest for a year, so the top coin on a stack can be flipped over to show that.

Fruit coin:These represent 5 acres of fruit orchards and have an apple on both top and bottom.

UPDATE: We have played with these now, at least once since I finished printing and finishing everything. The cows are perfectly sized to ride the tractor (so my 6-year old showed me), and yes, the cows tip forward and rest on their front legs and noses... Though, they are just the right height to rest their chins on the Hay, Grain, or Fruit tokens...

Printer:

Monoprice Mini Select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.4mm

Infill:

70%

Notes:

I printed these all in ABS Plastic:
Teal/Blue for Tractor and Harvester
Green for Hay
Yellow for Grain
Red for Fruit
White for Cows.

ABS Acetone Vapor Bath

For the Tractor, Harvester, Grain, Hay, and Fruit coins, I put them in a vapor bath for 30 minutes.

For the cows, due to their small size, I put them in a vapor bath for about 20 minutes

Cow Painting (Optional)

This is a Square motor brace

If you use different extruders, is a hassle to recalibrate your reprap each time you change the extruder. Therefore I decided to make my hobbet bolts much more precisely and reproducible. To gain better hobbet bolts, you need the little bolt hobbit and a proxxon micromot 50 (with some adjustment you might also be able to use any other kind of dremel-like tool). With the bolt hobbit, you can make a hobbet bolt with 32 teeth that are perfectly parallel, sharp and have the same dimensions. Furthermore it is easy to reproduce some identical bolts (that feed the exact same amount of filament per revolution to the hot end) so it is no longer necessary to recalibrate your firmware each time you change the extruder. This thing is slightly inspired by the KNRLR found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21782 but made much more rigid and handyer to rotate the bolt (can probably be used for mass-production of hobbed bolts :) ) edit 1: Added IGES design file
edit 2: I just made the first >6hour print with the new bolt (it was a print with a large number of retractions - the worst situation for the filament feeding system) and it worked absolutely flawless! Printing speed was up to 70mm/s in this print (40mm/s average).
edit 3: people who print another machine-holder (as found in derivates for example) can now download the standalone lever-only stl file in order to not have to print the proxxon-holder too.
edit 4: I just added a 30tooth gear for those of you who prefer less teeth on the hobbed bolt...

Materials used:
â¢M3 threaded rod
â¢M3 nuts (7pcs & 1x wing nut)
â¢M3 Screws (3pcs, about 20 - 25mm long each... longer ones work fine...)
â¢Two short pieces of plastic filament (Ã¸ 3mm)
â¢Washers (if you have... works without too...)
â¢Tensioner spring (out of an old ink jet or tape recorder... :) )
â¢All the printed parts enclosed with this thing... (zzz-lever_only.stl is optional, see edit 3!)
â¢Micromot50 with cutting disc tool Assembly
Depending on the length of the bolt you dare to hobb, you might want to slightly shorten the two spacer elements (blue on my photos) by a simple hacksaw...
  • Prepare pieces of M3 threaded rod (one longer and one shorter piece - mind the lever to block the gear)
  • Screw the frame togehter (use two short pieces of filament to block the higher spacer from rotating!)
  • Press the 3 Nuts into the machine flange
  • Screw the flange to the frame
  • Mount the spring to the little hooks (you can warm the hooks by a lighter and close them to prevent the spring to get lost...)
  • Press a bolt inside the gear
  • Mount gear and machine on the bolt hobbit
    • Hobbing a bolt:
  • Centre the cutting disc tool to hit the screw at the correct place.
  • Switch your micromot50 on and use highest available speed
  • Make sure, the gear is well centered and cut the first slot (not too deep, you can re-cut later if it is not deep enough)
  • Turn by one tooth and cut again (make sure the slot has the same lenght - then it will be exactly the same)
  • Repeat turning & cutting until you have one full resolution
  • Check result and re-cut if necessary until happy :)
    • Hint:
    Do not mount the cutting disc until your micromot is fixed inside the flange and remove the cutting disc BEFORE you unmount the micromot from the flange. I lost some discs due to breaking them while mounting... :P

comments.text: Wonderful little tool. Just remember, when you work with stainless steel, use cutting fluid (molybdenum based is my preference). Oils act as a solvent on the plastic, but keep the steel cool. SS work hardens and will blunt any tools you use (I once saw an apprentice spend 1/2 an hour drilling 2 holes in SS without  cutting fluid, because the drill bit was blunted within seconds of starting the first hole).
comments.author: MoonCactus

comments.text:
This apprentice probably did not value his time enough to ask why ;) I second your advice.
I did not use any oil b/c my bolts are not stainless steel ( http://www.tridimake.com/2013/03/which-hobbed-bolt-for-filament-feeder.htmlhttp://www.tridimake.com/2013/... ). Still I should try anyhow next time. It will also certainly be messier with a cutting wheel than with a drill ;)

remixed_from.author: huntley
remixed_from.title: 2020 Carriages for Magnetic Arms and Mini V-Wheels

description.text:
This is a remix of Hayden's 2020 carriage. I like his idea because makes the carriage very light and has the advantage of fine belt tensioning.
The differences are:
64mm rod spacing to work with the 64mm 3xPiezo Magnetic Effector here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2361081
and 3mm holes for M3 bolts to work with Delrin V-Wheels from http://www.think3dprint3d.com and 20mm wide extrusions from Motedis Profile 20 I-Type slot 5 http://www.motedis.co.uk/shop/Slot-profiles/Profile-20-I-Type-slot-5:::999991_99999133.html or Misumi http://uk.misumi-ec.com/vona2/detail/110302684350/?HissuCode=HFS5-2040-%5B50-4000%2F0.5%5D&PNSearch=HFS5-2040-%5B50-4000%2F0.5%5D&KWSearch=HFS5-2040&Keyword=HFS5-2040&searchFlow=results2products&Keyword=HFS5-2040

They have the same wheel spacing so can also work with extrusions and 15mm diameter V-wheels from OpenBuilds or RobotDigg.com if you modify the hole size. I've attached CAD files for this. If you need other formats please let me know.

Per carriage, you will need:
3x Delrin V-wheels from www.think3dprint3d.com
2x 10mm ball studs from Haydn http://www.MagBallArms.com
3x M3x30 bolts.
10x M5 nylock nuts
6x M3 washers
2x M3x35 hex bolts for the belt tightener.
2x M3 nuts for the belt tightener.
1x M3x40 hex bolt for preloading the carriage wheels.
1x M3x20 hex bolt for the vertical post for the lower G2 belt attachment.
1x M3x15 bolt for upper belt attachment
1x M2.5x12 hex for fine end stop tunning
9x M3x4mm spacers http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/142378241665

The spacers are to be placed between the bearings in each wheel. That helps a lot with wheel alignment.
Between every wheel and the carriage, there is one nylock nut and two washers. Is best to fit them first and measure all three with a caliper before you fit the wheels. This way you know all three wheels, when fitted, will be the same distance from the carriage. Nylock nuts can differ by as much as .4mm.
My Kossel is built with Robogigg metal corners and I've twisted the belt to run over the idler pulleys. They run very smooth this way.
Cable ties should not be necessary if part "b" and "c" are precisely printed.
Some of Robodigg f623zz bearings started being noisy after 6h of use so I've replaced them with some EZO made in Japan.

Enjoy!

description.text:
First of all, thanks to the JonDanielsRacing, and his design GoPro Flat Mount, that I modified.
The mount has been designed for the Xiaomi Yi camera, but it can be used for any other action camera that can be mounted by the buckle clip.
NOTE: The buckle clip has been bought with Kingma waterproof case for Xiaomi Yi and the camera mount model has been modified to fit it tightly. I'm not sure if it will fit the same for the other action camera buckle clips. So don't judged me if it doesn't.

Printer:

Felix 3.1

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

100 um or 150 um

Infill:

30%

Notes:

The slicing has been done with the KISSLICER v1.5 for single extruder. The support is needed due to curved part of the model that will be sewed later to the baseball cap front panels and the buckle clip insert part. If you have dual extruder printer print with two filaments, preferably with soluble one. In my case I printed with one extruder with the valid support settings: Coarse support, XY Gap 0.4, Z Gap 0.2, Flow Gain 0.35, Z Band 0.5, Raft Int Layers 1, Support 45 [deg]. Slow the print for the best results.

For those who will print the model and support with the same filament

Use some sharp knife for example scalpel to remove bigger parts of support. Afterwards, scrap off the remaining support residue with sand paper. The surface does not need to be cleaned to perfection because the bottom part of the model will be sewed later to the baseball cap front panels.
Before sewing if the holes are not big enough for the needle to go through, make them bigger with some sharp tool or drill them with the power tool. For sewing I used thicker thread. The sewing has been exhausting but it was worth it.

Kingma buckle clip

The buckle clip has been bought with Kingma water proof case for Xiaomi Yi and the camera mount model has been modified to fit it tightly. I'm not sure if it will fit the same for GoPro buckle, so don't judged me if it doesn't.
The action camera mount has been designed to be sewed to front panels of the baseball cap.

author: chsc

description.text:
Per Request, this is the back clip for the Cassian Blaster Pistol.

I consider this to be "in the style of" the movie prop and not 100% accurate.
In short the movie prop is made from an airsoft rifle.

I found airsoft rifles that had the removable stock with the correct clip on the back like in the movie, but the right hand side detail was all wrong.

I also found airsoft rifles with the correct right hand side detail, but not the removable, clip on stock.

I never found the exact airsoft rifle the movie prop people used. (I'm guessing it is only available in Europe or something like that. Or costs $300 as i was not looking to cut up expensive airsoft rifles.)

It was easiest for me to print the back part for the clip on stock for the correct, right hand side detail.
This is for looks only and is just glued on. It is not meant to support a stock, or to clip in with any existing stock.

comments.text: The pistol is actually made from an AR-15 upper and lower not an airsoft gun but from real gun parts.
comments.author: koideath

comments.text: I've done a fair amount of research and I honestly think it is not a real AR-15 upper. Actual AR Uppers have a cylindrical part on the back that the stock screws into. The prop gun in the movie has a tab that a stock can slide onto. I have seen that style of sliding on a stock in airsoft guns. I have yet to see that style in an actual AR-15.  If you have photo references let me know, I could not find any suggesting it was an actual AR Upper.
comments.author: koideath

comments.text: I have built a lot of actual AR-15's and I can tell you that they do use an actual AR upper, lower, grip, charging handle, dust cover, 10 round mag, mag release, trigger guard, bolt release, forward assist, and mil-spec trigger. I have all the parts to assemble one right now minus the greeblies, barrel, and the back plate. The cylinder you are talking about is called the buffer tube and it screws into the lower receiver. The buffer tube is what the stock slides onto They simply created a plate to go on the back of the AR lower to cover the hole. Plus the star wars franchise as always reused real guns in their prop making mostly from WW2. Like how Han Solos blaster is actually a Mauser C96 used in WW1 and WW2 by the Germans. Search AR-15 exploded view to see how all the parts fit together.
comments.author: Jswigg

comments.text:
While I agree with you that at least episodes 4, 5, and 6 used actual modified guns, I stand by my comment that Rogue One used airsoft guns. First off, I'd like to point out that any movie prop gun could have a number of different guns made from real guns to fire blanks, some made from airsoft guns that are lighter, some cast and molded in resin, some molded in rubber. There is no singular gun used on a set.
That said, here is a link to DK the people that do the visual dictionaries stating that Rogue One used airsoft guns (See pic #4)
https://www.dk.com/us/explore/star-wars/10-incredible-behind-the-scenes-photos-from-rogue-one-a-star-wars-story/
comments.author: koideath

comments.text: You hit the nail on the head when you said there is no single prop. Cassians blaster had many different versions. Resin one for running scenes, and specially modified pneumatic one for shooting action scenes. Usually though hero props would be made. Ones that feel and look like a real gun up close. They would be used for close up shots. They probably used some cheap mass produced airsoft for storm troopers or resin variant. Speaking of airsoft. That one article mentions using airsoft for realistic recoil. An airsoft gun isn't going to create realistic recoil. They would need some sort of pneumatic system like what the military uses for training.
comments.author: Jswigg

Wanna print an industrial looking fidget spinner, which won't break after falling?
Meet this new design I just made!

If you have any questions or comments please share!

Notes:

Printing a raft would benefit the overall quality of the print!

Required components

For this build you will need the following components:

  • 1x 36mm diameter precision bearing
  • 4x M8 bolts
  • 4x M8 nuts
  • Super glue
  • 1x Fidget Spinner.stl
  • 2x Fidget Spinner_Cap.stl
36mm bearing Bearing assembly

The main bodu is designed with a press fit. You would need to hamer te bearing in place gently. Otherwise you would damage the bearing.

Bearing 1/2 true the hole Cap assembly and bolt assembly

Place 1 cap in the bearing. Put in upside down. Apply some super glue true the bearing hole and place the second cap on top of it. Let is rest for a couple of hours so that it will remain at his place.

After the cap assembly you can easily mount the bolts in to the designed places. It is also possible to use M12 bolts to get the spinner even heavier. This will likely not result in a higher spin speed or time.

Mounted M12 bolts

description.text: I had a bunch of post processing tools, pens, glue, etc. sitting on my desk, so I decided to make this handy little organizer to store everything and maintain first order retrievability(thanks to Adam Savage for that concept) Its primary features are a wide solid base to prevent tipping, tall center section to hold large tools like screwdrivers, scrapers, pens, etc. The outer cups offer a wide open mouth to easily retrieve shorter objects like nippers, super glue, and even the small allen wrench that came with my printer.

Make sure your wall thickness is set to be three layers, or if your slicer insists on 2 layers of wall due to nozzle diameter, then turn on infill to bond the the layers together.
This is a pure utility device, so all I did for post was to pull the few strings that had occurred, and put it into use!

Designed in Fusion 360. Sketched out the 9 tubes on a base, extruded the rings. Then sketched a spline and created a revolve cut to get the unique shape. Added fillets to the base, and it was complete.

title: Ultralight 720p actioncam using Hubsan X4 H107C camera module

description.text:
Buddy wanted the files to print one of these so I figured I'd just publish it in case anyone else wants it.

I bought a Hubsan X4 H107C a few years back and felt it flew like a whale. In an effort to make it more responsive, I ended up ripping out anything non-essential. This included removing the built in camera module. Recently I've gotten into the micro brushless FPV quads and wanted a onboard camera to record the flight without all the static from the VTX. Problem was even the runcam HD and mobius was too heavy, so I dragged out the hubsan camera module and made this case to hold everything in place. It has openings for the record switch and microsd slot.

You can buy the modules by themselves, just search for H107C-A34 for the 720p camera module or H107C-A28 for the older standard def camera.

I wasn't planning on ever opening it up, so instead of screws, I just heat staked the top and the bottom together with a soldering iron. Works like a charm and weighs next to nothing. If I had to recase this, I would use thinner wires and skip the JST connector, the ones I used ended up being a significant portion of the entire weight!

This unit is compatible with the original SD camera and the newer 720p camera module from the H107C. No idea if the camera from the H107C+ works, but its possible.

I printed it at 0.1mm height with no support or rafts.

P.S. Somewhat obviously, flip the lid over 180 degrees to print. Its in the default orientation that Fusion360 exported the component (which was part of an assembly)

P.P.S. Camera runs off 3.3V.

title: 80mm Fan Inlet/Outlet for Camping and more

description.text:
Update 10.Jun. 2017: Replaced "80mmFanOutsideInnlet.stl" -> With better stability and also printable abbiltys. The side with the opening, without the Net-Structure and additional Edge should faced down on the Heatbed for best Printperformance! Watch the Screenshot from Cura!

This are my solutions for my Camping-Caddy to get fresh Air while Sleeping. Two 80mm Fans bring in and out the Air of the Caddy. The Outside Covers for the fans are mainly for Weather-Protection. So there is a Drip-Edge for the Outside inlet while its raining that should help to get no additional water inside the Car. Also the inside Covers have a functional Background. So should the InsideOutlet took the Bad Air from the top of the car outside. The inlet blows wide in the car with a angled nozzle.

The Fans will controlled from a Arduino. The Arduino is getting data from inside and outside of the Car. Because it makes no sense to run the Fans all night long.

I will link the Arduino-Sketch after my first Realtime-test...

remixed_from.title: M2-Extruder tighened up throat for Flexible materials

title: Makergear M2 V4 hotend Extruder tightened up throat for Flexible materials

description.text:
I have upgraded my Makergear M2 from the 3Vb, to the V4 hotend and had to recreate this extruder mod for soft materials for my M2. Just installed it this past weekend and I am conducting testing at this time. So far and works good I will post pictures later. I made mine from PETG,

S3D factory file included with supports and PETG profile,

Settings that I use when printing ninjaflex.

I use the following with a M2 Std. .35mm nozzle on painter tape for ninjaflex.

3mm extrusion retractions
2400mm/min retraction speed
.20mm Wipe
Extruder 215 Deg. C
Bed off
Layer 1 fan off. Other 100%
Default print speed 2000mm/min

Loading the Extruder must be done slower that PLA or ABS. I turn down my feed on the extruder to 200mm/min for loading. Also helps to do loading 10mm at a time till all the old filament is expelled.

Update 6/9/17
Testing completed with PLA, ABS, PETG, and Ninjaflex. Shoved everything though the hot end like a boss

comments.text: I use all materials in it . No need to change out.
comments.author: Dfr2923

comments.text: Would this be a bad idea to print in PLA?
comments.author: YoBoyCal

comments.text: Due to the proximity to the hot end and heat rising off the bed I would say PLA would be a poor choice. ABS works well but I have had fatigue cracks form over time on heat cycled parts. I have fount PETG or PET+ to be the most robust materials in components that have to be hard, tough, wear resistant, flexible, and able to handle many heat and cooling cycles. PETG I have found to print fine on blue painters tape with no bed heat.

author: Kav3na

description.text:
I've been converting wood puzzles into plastic lately. This is the next one.  
The 12 pieces fit together to form a star-like shape. This is not the toughest puzzle around, as everything is symmetrical, so you should be able to figure it out.  
Have fun.

comments.text: Made the mistake of making one, assuming that the solution "was easy", but no - it really isn't, without starting with some notion of an assembled puzzle to analyze and reverse engineer...  According to Wikipedia, there are billions of possible ways to try to assemble these types of component parts, made worse by the fact that you have no idea what the component sub-assemblies need to look like to begin with.   No one on the Internet seems to have any guide for assembling a puzzle with this many pieces either, so the whole effort has been a waste.

This is just the same robot as http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18264 But I've created a new part: spacers. Their objective is to support the Arduino board, allowing to place a 9V battery below it. Its advantage is that the battery is just above the wheels, so the grip is slightly increased :) The Arduino code which makes it able to navigate inside a corridor is also attached. Video of NS-1 working here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xKkJGlzjeCM

Print and mount! Files attached: spacers.stl and spacers.scad and navigation.pde (Arduino code) The main chassis and wheels can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18264 The scad has been generated using the OOML library ( http://iearobotics.com/oomlwiki/ ) but I don't share the OOML code because it is really really ugly. Anyway, if you want it just ask me.

title: IKEA closet enclosure filament hole Ver.2 (sponge filter)

description.text:
Hi, I want to guide through the IKEA closet filament. So I made plastic tube that you can use after the drill hole. In this Ver. 2 added inside the tube filter holder.

  1. Drill the hole with the 35mm tool (IKEA Article Number: 203.023.32))
  2. Print it out this *.STL
  3. Have a sponge (in my case dish washing sponge :-)).
  4. Mount tube.
  5. Insert filament.
  6. Mount sponge as shown in the picture.

:-)

This larger capacity design still fits on the same size build plate if you print 4 arms in one print run, and the hub in another.

Arms included to hold 2, 3, 4 and 5 filaments

title: Kossel Delta Spool Holder with Hard Drive Bearing

description.text:
I had seen different spool holders and wanted to combine a lot of what I saw into what I wanted. I wanted something that would attach to a 2020 rail system, could be mounted in different configurations, and utilized a bearing for a smooth action. This holder combines a 3.5 hard drive bearing and the parts you print and 5 total screws and 2 t-nuts.

On my application, I used M4 x 8mm screws and M4 t-nuts to secure the mount to the rail. I reused the screws from dissasembling the hard drive and the bearing to assemble the rest. Assembly should go in this order: 1) M4 screws and nuts attached to printed mount. Leave nuts loose. 2) Mount hard drive bearing to printed mount. 3) Attach mount to 2020 rail and tighten it down to secure it. 4) Attach screw to exposed side of bearing and secure with screws. Rotate the bearing to see the exposed screw holes on the side of the mount. 5) Attach spool and secure with printed nut.

The advantage of this design is that it is useful for many types of spools/filament and it can be mounted in any orientation on the 2020 rail. Also, please rotate the mount 180 degrees so that it will be printed with the circles indentations facing up.

title: FIdget Spinner 608 Bearing Cap Snap In

description.text:
Thanks to all the great users of this community, I have been able to make many really awesome things. I felt it was time I gave back.

This idea came from this thing:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2130642

While I did the design myself in OpenSCAD without any reverse engineering from the original, I really liked the orignal.

My problem with the original was that it just didn't sit tightly enough in my bearings and would come out too easy. Also, I needed a higher lip under the thumb rest because of the design of my fidget spinner (slightly thicker than a 608 bearing).

I also tried several other designs including ones that glued together (didn't like that, too hard to take apart), a threaded one - really neat concept but didn't work quite the way I wanted, a two piece that pressed together - but again this required glue.

So in the end after printing more than 7 or 8 different caps from Thingiverse, I decided to make my own. I hope it works for you.

Version 1.0 Dated: 29 June 2017.

This is a Front Mounted Layer Fan For The Tevo Tarantula.

It is intended for use with my [E3D V6 & BLtouch X Axis Carrier for Tarantula Re-Mix] (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2368256). This thing screws directly to the front of the X Axis Carrier Clamp. If you refer to the main image of this Front Mounted Layer Fan, the parts printed in Orange belong to the (E3D V6 & BLtouch X Axis Carrier for Tarantula Re-Mix) [https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2368256].

I have designed the Upper Fan Duct to accept a 4020 DC Fan (12 Volt, 6000 RPM). The fan that I used is an Alseye 4020. At full speed, this 6000 RPM fan provides an adequate cooling airflow over the print job. I needed to fit a Teflon Sock over the E3Dv6 Hotend to prevent the fan's airflow from over-cooling the hotend.

The Upper Fan Duct slides over the outside of the Lower Fan Duct. The clearance of the Lower Fan Duct above the print bed can be adjusted by sliding the Lower Fan Duct into or out of the Upper Fan Duct. Once the correct placement has been established, I glued the Upper Fan Duct to the Lower Fan Duct using Super Glue.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula E3Dv6 & BLTouch-Smart

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 Layer Height in Cura

Infill:

20%

Notes:

After some experimentation, I found that the Upper Fan Duct prints best if it is inverted on the build plate.

The Lower Fan Duct has three internal vanes that are designed to provide bridging support. These vanes also help to direct and smooth out the airflow. Cura sliced and printed these vanes correctly.

However, my first test print using Slic3r, failed to print the vanes, and instead Slic3r blocked the inside of the duct with support material that was impossible to remove due to lack of access.

**Support Removal**

Using Cura, the supports are easily removed during post-printing clean-up.

On the lower Fan Duct, the outlet opening is a 3mm wide circular slot opening in the bottom side of the duct. When using Cura, the support material completely filled the outlet opening, making it appear that there was no opening. However, the support material filling the outlet is easily removed.

**Hardware Required**

All screw holes provided in this item are formed as Pilot Holes. You will need to drill out the pilot holes to a size that suits the type and style of fastener that you choose.

I used 3mm x 25mm Socket Head Cap Screws to Mount the Fan onto the Upper Fan Duct. I drilled the pilot holes to 2.4mm and then tapped threads using a 3mm Intermediate Tap. Some people may choose to use 3mm Self Tapping Screws suitable for plastic - with the pilot holes drilled to a suitable size.

I use 3mm x 30mm Socket Head Cap Screws to mount the Upper Fan Duct onto the Clamp on the Front of the [X Axis E3D Carrier]https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2368256).

title: Modular vacuum table/clamp for small cnc machines
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Vacuum clamp/table for smaller cnc machines/routers. It contains modules 50x50mm which, once printed, you can connect as you wish, glueing it toghether. You can make table big as you want, by printing lot of this modules. It contains side, middle, angle and connector modules which, combined, make one whole table. Modules are 10mm high.
It also contains connector in which you can screw in PTFE tube connector for making vacuum. In future i will make vacuum cleaner adaptor.

Print, glue toghether, you can also apply various chemicals for making it shine and airtight. In grooves you can add rubbers for making better vacuum contact. You will probably need to sand sides for better sealing.

Print flat, without support, but make sure you put 100% infill, so therefore it will not make problems when you make vacuum. You can also use some kind of polisher or glue for plastic, which once it hardened it will make airtight seals.

If you have any idea how to improve this design, feel free to post it, and if you make this, feel free to post pictures.

comments.text: how is your performance with octopi on the  Raspberry Pi Zero W ? i´m looking to put octoprint on my printer but i don´t now if the zero W is powerfull enought or i need the Pi 3 for good performance with camera, etc.
comments.author: JDCAVALLO

comments.text: I just compared OctoPi printing and file upload performance on a Raspberry Pi Zero W and a Pi 3 and found the performance to be the same. There seems to be a serial bottleneck caused by the pyserial library used to handle serial communication or the baud rate itself, so I use a computer to put gcode on an SD card, then put the SD card in the printer and start the print from OctoPi. The printer only slows down when printing lots of vertices in a tight grouping (like small holes or rounded corners). I made a quick video comparing the two printing modes here: https://youtu.be/Ssr-MKMt2H8

title: GEPRC LX5 "Leopard" Rx Antenna Arm Mounts

description.text:
These are arm mounts for Rx antennas. I didn't like how the XT60 leads kind of pushed to on my previous design bringing the antennas dangerously close to the props. Even though I always run 3mm OD plastic tubing around my antennas I thought I could do better there.

So this design is inspired on how the Helix (and probably other frames now too) run the antenna 90 degree from the arms.

These mounts are super light, work for both and right arm. I recommend TPU as it just never breaks (100% in-fill here since it's so small).

My Youtube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCRcH4GVpY6f2bHH0l0d6-qA

I print these using PLA and apply glaze coat epoxy with a fine paint brush to seal the inner walls.

The numbers inside can be difficult to see, I use a fine paint brush and acrylic paint to fill the numbers for contrast.

I designed this jigger using FreeCAD. I drew the profile of the walls and rotated it around the vertical axis.

A skate spinner is a device that is used by figure skaters for training spins off-ice.  It is like the sole of a shoe with a curved surface below.  You step on top of it and start spinning.  It is both a good training device and a funny (if you learn to keep your balance!) toy.

A skate spinner is a device that is used by figure skaters for training spins off-ice. It consists of a flat platform with a curved surface (the rocker) below. To use the spinner, put it on the floor, step on the platform and just spin while maintaining your balance. If you have never used a spinner, start slowly and remember that you can fall down if you are not careful. The platform should be roughly the size of a foot. The rocker is around 1000 mm for typical skate spinners. A skate spinner is too big for many amateur-level manufacturing machines, but it can be cut (use difference()) into small pieces that can be glued or welded together. The model is fully parametric. You can look at the scad source and tinker with the parameters. A note for choosing the dimensions and building: Due to the limited stiffness of some materials, it is necessary to choose the dimensions of the spinner properly. The spinner will bend under weight and it might end squashed on the floor, the otherwise curved rocker completely plane. You can use the following equation borrowed from elementary beam theory to estimate your dimensions: k < 1 / R, where: R = rocker_radius (remember that it is defined in mm);
k = bending curvature = M / (E I);
E = Young's modulus (about 2,3 GPa for ABS);
M = bending moment = W l / 4;
W = weight (in the order of 1000 N);
l = back_length + middle_length + front_length (remember: mm);
I = area moment of inertia = (1 / 12) (b h^3 - (b - 2 t) (h - 2 t)^3);
b = width = minimum of back_width and front_width (remember: mm);
h = maximum section height = H + l^2 / (8 R);
H = platform_thickness (remember that it is defined in mm);
t = wall thickness of your build (it will depend on how you slice the model; with H = 15 mm, l = 260 mm, b = 700 mm and R = 900 mm and ABS material, t = 4 mm has proven to be a good choice). After bending, the radius of curvature of the rocker grows (thus approaching the infinite radius of a planar surface) to roughly the following value: 1 / (1 / R - k), so keep a good margin between k and 1 / R. Apart from the stiffness criterion, you need to keep the material from breaking. With this simple model, the maximum stress will be found at the highest point of the middle section and it will be M h / (2 I). Keep this well below the tensile strength of the material (which is roughly 35 MPa in the case of ABS). Actually, there will be important stress concentrations at other points (where the section width starts changing, for example) which are not covered by this simple physical model. Also, if you build the pieces vertically (i.e. stacking layers along the lengthwise direction), then the actual strength will be the cohesive strength between layers, which can be quite lower than the tensile strength of the material, and there will be certain risk of sudden delaminations. With ABS, smoothing the surfaces by rubbing with a solvent like acetone helps aleviate this weakness and the material can be solvent-welded (with a solution of ABS and acetone or butanone) to give quite bonds that have a strength that is comparable to that of the bulk material. If the spinner is too big for your machine, you can divide it in several pieces. ABS pieces can be solvent-welded together with a solution of ABS and acetone or ABS and butanone. Provided that you apply some pressure (press the pieces together with your hands) for several seconds and then let the bonding dry for 24 hours, you will get a quite strong bond. The excess material from the welding can be sanded easily.

author: Gerdes

title: Build Frog Race Frog Lite 218mm Quad

description.text: Frog Race Frog Lite is a beautiful frame with Carbon Fiber 4mm Arm, it's an easy build and weighs in at only 286g. I really liked this frame, and I decided to build a Frog Race Frog Lite 218mm quad. This build supports Dshot600 and offers OSD for voltage monitoring and a built-in blackbox for tuning. It can easily carry a Session or Runcam 3 with a bottom mounted battery, but you can top mount at the cost of an HD cam. These motors are great middle-tier motors, so you've got a wide variety of prop options. I'd probably avoid running 5051s, but you should be fine running up to 5048s.

Part List

Frame: Frog Race Frog Lite 218mm Carbon Fiber 4mm Arm X Frame DIY Frame Kit (4 builds) $27.99

Flight Controller: Omnibus Betaflight F4 Flight Controller V1 STM32 F405 MCU Integrated OSD (17 builds) $24.49

ESCs: TATTU 30A BLHeli_S ESC (2-5S, w/Dshot, No BEC) for FPV RC model (4pcs) $67.96

Motors: 4x Emax RS2205S 2300KV Racing Edition Brushless Motor for FPV Racing (25 builds) $74.00

Propellers: DAL Cyclone Tri-Blade 5″ Prop – T5046C 5″ (50 builds) $2.99
RTF Premium 5040 QUADBLADE Prop (Smoke) $0.99

FPV Camera: Runcam Swift Mini 130 Degree 2.5mm Micro FPV Camera Build in OSD PAL/NTSC Orange/Black 22*22mm (8 builds) $34.99

FPV Transmitter: Eachine VTX03 Super Mini 5.8G 72CH 0/25mW/50mw/200mW Switchable FPV Transmitter (70 builds) $13.99

Receiver: Frsky XM+ Micro D16 SBUS Full Range Receiver Up to 16CH (66 builds) $12.99

Batteries: Tattu R-Line 1550mAh 95C 4S1P lipo battery pack with XT60 Plug $44.88

Misc Parts:

  • RunCam RC21/RC23/RC25 FPV Lens 2.1mm/2.3mm/2.5mm FOV 165/150/130 Degree Wide Angle for Swift Swift2 Mini $8.99
  • 5 Pairs Black XT60 Bullet Connector Plugs for RC Battery (2 builds) $4.99
  • 2 x 4 PCS Realacc M3*7+4.5 Flight Controller Anti-Vibration Fixed Screws for FPV Racer (3 builds) $5.58
  • 550 Paracord Black Jet Black Made in USA (2 builds)

Others
Apart from the parts listed below you’ll need a few additional items that no bench should be without:

  • A nylon nut set with 2mm nuts and 1mm spacers
  • Shrink tubing
  • 20awg wire
  • Double sided tape
  • Zip ties
  • Blue loctite
Making it Fit

The frame is a little tight, but they offered some extension pieces to raise the stack area by about 4-5mm. If you have a large RX you may need to use them, but an XM+, X4R or Spektrum Satellite should fit fine without them. There's very little documentation, so it's not obvious what these are for. I've seen these extensions used on the back of the frame where the LED panel goes for stack protection and possibly a resting place for a larger antenna. The longer pieces only add about 1mm above the stack, so I don't see much reason to use these.

Finding the right standoffs to build the stack was a challenge, but I found the perfect combination. If you aren’t using the extensions you can use the 10mm screws to start to the stack. I added 2mm nuts with 1mm spacers. The spacers are important because you’ll end up with too much threading for the vibration dampening standoffs. These also offer just enough room to run a battery strap under the ESC board. While the 4-in-1 ESC came with an assortment of nylon standoffs, they’re all far too tall for this frame. You’d probably end up with a 30mm stack if you used those.

Wiring the Motors

Unfortunately EMAX hasn’t caught on to the 4-in-1 trend, so the motor wires were too short. Dig through your wire bin for some 20awg wire as you’ll need only about 12 inches of it. If you need to buy some, be sure to pick up some 14awg and 16awg just to have around for future builds. First you need to screw the motors onto the arms. Use some blue loctite to ensure the screws won’t wiggle loose. Now to extend the wires you want to lay each wire down onto the arm to get the length just right. Touch the end of the extension to the nearest ESC pad, snip, solder and repeat. Finish each joint off with some shrink tubing and you can optionally add some 550 paracord for added protection.

This 4-in-1 ESC is great because it has a 5v regulator that can handle up to 3amps. The Omnibus F4 also has a built-in 5v reg, but it doesn’t support enough amperage to run both the VTX and camera. The ESC plugs directly into the FC using the included connector and the 5v power is passed through the red wire. Now if you’d like a voltage reading via OSD you’ll also need to send power to the vbat pins, but the FC will favor the 5v from the ESC to power both itself and the RX. You’ll need to bridge the RAM and 5V pins to pass power to the VTX/camera.

One thing to note is that this FC uses a linear regulator to produce 5v from vbat. Since we aren’t using the 5v from the FC it will produce unnecessary heat. I didn’t do this, but it is an option if heat becomes a problem. You can also exclude vbat if you don’t need the OSD voltage reading. This would also reduce the heat.

One thing to note is this frame doesn’t come with an XT60 connector, so you’ll have to buy a set of them. I used the black ones listed in the part list. Snip the wires short enough that they won’t pull the battery leads into prop strike range, but not so short that your shrink tube shrinks before you can sleeve it over the terminals.

Mounting the Camera

I chose the Runcam Swift mini for the size and weight reduction, but the frame isn’t necessarily designed for it. You’ll have to use the included conversion bracket which offers a nice snug fit. It should be pretty clear which screw holes to use here, but if you have any questions review the photos below. The only thing I’d like to add is that you should use the nylon washers included with the Runcam outside the aluminum plates. This gives you a nice tight fit.

Wiring the Flight Control

This is a fairly straightforward wiring job, but be sure to pull up an Omnibus F4 board diagram to follow along. Mainly what you need to do is wire the camera and VTX and jump the 5v/RAM pins to send them power. Check the photo below for the big blob of solder just below the RX wires to see where to jump the RAM pins. This mainly passes the 5v from the 4-in-1 to the RAM pins along the VTX/camera rails. Also, I soldered the RX to the inverted UART which functions as UART1 in Betaflight. Finally, I passed power straight from the battery to the vbat pins to monitor voltage via OSD.

Mounting the RX and VTX

Since the XM+ antennas are extremely long I rotated the U.fl connectors to send the antennas back around the RX. This reduced the length by a few cm which offered the perfect length to send the antennas behind the front arms. You can see how I passed the antennas under the motor wires along zip ties secured with shrink tubing. To mount the VTX I added about 3 layers of double sided tape beside the display, added a wad of hot glue to the U.fl connector and taped it to the bottom of the top plate. I used a zip tie to keep the little dipole antenna from falling down into the props.

Configuration

If you wire the motors as illustrated they won’t be in the proper positions in BetaFlight, but BF 3.1 has a great resource command which lets you swap motor positions. You never need to worry about motor wire positions or swapping wires to set the rotation. All of this can be changed in software and allows for the cleanest wiring possible. Here’s a short checklist to follow before you maiden:

  • Flash firmware to the latest version of BF.
  • Use resource commands to order the motors.
  • Use BLHeli Configurator to set motor rotations.
  • Bind TX/RX and set inputs and ranges.
  • Set switches to arm and change modes.
  • Configure OSD.
  • Set your rates.
  • Use camera OSD to adjust your camera settings

RTF Premium 5040 QUADBLADE Prop (Smoke) $0.99 FPV Camera: Runcam Swift Mini 130 Degree 2.5mm Micro FPV Camera Build in OSD PAL/NTSC Orange/Black 22*22mm (8 builds) $34.99 FPV Transmitter: Eachine VTX03 Super Mini 5.8G 72CH 0/25mW/50mw/200mW Switchable FPV Transmitter (70 builds) $13.99 Receiver: Frsky XM+ Micro D16 SBUS Full Range Receiver Up to 16CH (66 builds) $12.99 Batteries: Tattu R-Line 1550mAh 95C 4S1P lipo battery pack with XT60 Plug $44.88 Misc Parts:

author: olivaleonardo

description.text:
Most spectrophotometers are designed to hold a 1 cm cuvette with outer dimensions of 12.5 X 12.5 mm, however it is often desirable to use a cuvette with a shorter path-length.  
This thing generates an adaptor that will stably position cuvettes that are thinner (in the beam path dimension) than the typical 1 cm pathlength cells in a spectrophotometer.  
(The current version assumes that the cuvette is just as wide as the sample compartment in the dimension perpendicular to the beam path.)

The included .stl and default customizer settings are for adapting a 1 mm cuvette (Starna, 21-G-1) to a typical 12.5 X 12.5 mm spectrophotometer sample compartment.  
For generating an adaptor for any cuvette using Customizer measure the outer dimension of your cuvette along the beam path.  Then measure the sample compartment of the spectrophotometer you are adapting it to.  The bottom thickness can be adjusted to accommodate different beam heights of various instruments.  
The current version of the .scad file assumes the cuvette is as wide as the sample cell holder.

author: Stef263

title: Tevo Tarantula MKS Gen-L Plate w/MOSFET
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I decided to switch to a MKS Gen-L so I could replace NEMA 17 drivers when/if needed, but I still wanted to use my original plates. While I was designing the new plate, I decided I'd add a side pod to mount a MOSFET out of the way (this MOSFET if you're thinking of using this https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B01HEQVQAK/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1). I'm still very much a beginner with Fusion 360, so if you can do it more elegantly, please feel free to remix it (and drop me a line so I can see what you did and hopefully learn from it).
The MOSFET is taller than the MKS Gen board obviously, so you might need to use taller offsets than the stock ones from the Tarantula. The sketches in 360 should allow you to print the MOSFET cover separately from the MKS cover. I haven't printed it yet or I'd tell you all for sure if that's the case.

6/28/17: Revision on the back plate. I discovered the holes didn't line up with the stock Tevo mounting plate (about 3mm off), so I put a revised version up. If you aren't using the plate in question, it shouldn't matter.

title: wHoop race gate
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted a larger diameter race gate for my buddies and me while flying our FPV quads, so I came up with the wHoop! Each foot has the name and a cavity where you can stash weights for stability or electronics (I'm working on a ring of LEDs and the battery pack and micro controller will hide out there).

It's about 14" (369mm) across on the inside, from flat edge to flat edge.

This is a stout race gate that prints in 6 pieces (2 feet and 4 segments). The quadrants of the hoop use dovetail joints that are a good fit. Your mileage may vary. You can glue it all together for the ultimate in rigidity or just slide it together and tear it down again for easy storage after race day.

I included a couple STLs I used to confirm good fit with the dovetail joints before committing to printing the hoop segments.

EDIT: I finished my follow-on project - a sonar sensor housing which I mounted onto my race gate to get some blinky light action when a quad runs through (but not over or around) the gate. Super cool!

https://youtu.be/1xWfArDQYAE

description.text:
This is a very simple development board for the PIC16F628a (or any other 18 pin pic with the the ICSP on the same pins).

It has an ICSP pin header for use with a PICKIT2 (or anything that is compatible with it) and the three rows of pins: one for the microcontroller pins, one connected to the 5v and one to the gnd, arranged in a way that makes it easy to connect a servo or any other module directly to the board, without the need for a breadboard.

It has a built-in led on the RB5 pin, a reset button, a DC jack, AMS1117a regulator and a power led. There are pads for an external crystal oscillator and 22pf capacitors.

The ingredient list:

  • One PIC16F628a and a 18 pin DIP socket
  • Two 3mm leds.
  • Two 10k resistors
  • Two 1k resistors
  • Two electrolytic capacitors of any value above 4.7uf and of any voltage rating above 16v
  • One omron-like tactile switch
  • One AMS1117-5v (it can be a lower voltage one like the 3v3 version, but you'll need to change the 1k resistors to make the LEDs bright enough on 3v3).
  • 3 x 16 male or female pin headers
  • 1 x 5 or 6 pin male or female pin header (for the ICSP).
  • One 4 to 20 mhz HC49 crystal oscillator and two 22 pf capacitors. Not necessary if you're going to use the internal oscillator.

Etch the board, solder everything in. Keep the component leads to make the jumpers. Download your program to the board with a PICKIT2 or compatible.

That's about it!

title: Solder iron cleaning station (With lid)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I often use my soldering iron for short projects, before putting it away. I don't like the wet sponge for cleaning soldering irons as it needs to dry out before storage. Curly brass cleaners are ideal, but most holders aren't ideal for chucking into an electronics toolbox as they are open designs and stuff can fall out.

I developed this to solve both problems, giving me a nice holder for the brass wool, and allowing me to close the cleaner so I could chuck it in my tool box without spilling stuff everywhere.

There's also an alternative, more amusing version. This hasn't been printed or tested, but some may enjoy it. :D

comments.author: Kittish

comments.text: Tried three times to print - twice using the suggested settings, once with my "normal" settings. Each time resulted in failed prints. Suspecting that my printer was to blame, I tried another file and it worked perfectly. I wasn't able to get a successful print of this thing.
comments.author: dgrimal

comments.text: Can I ask in what way or where was it failing?
comments.author: dgrimal

comments.text: Using a Prusa i3 clone with PLA, I first begin with Slic3r Prusa Edition (from within Repetier Host) which lays down the "primer" ring - two loops. It then begins to lay down the feet of the tray, which seem to go quite well for the first few layers. After that, something grabs (retraction settings not correct maybe?) and drags the printed parts around the platform eventually collecting in a glob of molten plastic.
comments.author: SpaceKiwi

comments.text: I've had a similar problem in the past. For me, it was because the hot bed cooled down and the print lost its grip on the bed. The feet themselves have a small surface area on the bed, so they could be being knocked off. Try using a raft, in this case. If you do think it is your retraction settings, try one of the retraction tests on this site and see how it goes.
comments.author: dgrimal
